source_text: Bubble sort is a simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly steps through the list, compares adjacent elements, and swaps them if they are in wrong order. The algorithm continues until no more swaps are needed, indicating the list is sorted.
generated_claim: Bubble sort requires comparing adjacent elements
evidence_span: repeatedly steps through the list, compares adjacent elements

source_text: An array is a contiguous block of memory storing elements of the same type. Arrays provide O(1) random access time because elements can be located directly using index arithmetic.
generated_claim: Arrays have constant time random access
evidence_span: Arrays provide O(1) random access time

source_text: Linear search checks each element in a list sequentially until finding the target. In the worst case, all elements must be checked.
generated_claim: Linear search worst case is O(n)
evidence_span: In the worst case, all elements must be checked

source_text: A linked list is a data structure where elements are stored in nodes with pointers to the next node. To access the kth element, you must traverse k nodes starting from the head.
generated_claim: Linked lists require linear time to access the kth element
evidence_span: To access the kth element, you must traverse k nodes

source_text: Binary search requires a sorted array. It repeatedly divides the search space in half, achieving O(log n) time complexity.
generated_claim: Binary search works on unsorted arrays

source_text: A stack is a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) data structure where elements are added and removed from the same end called the top.
A queue is a First-In-First-Out (FIFO) data structure where elements are added at the back and removed from the front.
Merge sort divides the array in half, recursively sorts each half, then merges them back. This guarantees O(n log n) time complexity in all cases.
generated_claim: Merge sort time complexity is always O(n log n)
evidence_span: This guarantees O(n log n) time complexity in all cases

source_text: A binary tree node has at most two children, called left and right children.
generated_claim: Binary tree nodes have exactly two children

source_text: Big O notation describes the upper bound of an algorithm's growth rate as input size increases infinitely.
generated_claim: Big O notation measures worst-case complexity

source_text: Recursion is when a function calls itself. Every recursive function needs a base case to stop the recursion.
generated_claim: Recursive functions need a base case
evidence_span: base case to stop the recursion

source_text: Hash tables use a hash function to compute an index into an array of buckets. Average lookup time is O(1).
generated_claim: Hash tables have O(1) average lookup time

source_text: Insertion sort builds a sorted array one item at a time by inserting each element into its correct position. It has O(n^2) worst-case time complexity.
generated_claim: Insertion sort worst case is O(n^2)
evidence_span: It has O(n^2) worst-case time complexity

source_text: Space complexity measures the amount of memory an algorithm uses as a function of input size.
Depth-first search (DFS) explores a graph by going as deep as possible before backtracking. It uses a stack for implementation.
generated_claim: DFS uses a stack for implementation
evidence_span: It uses a stack for implementation
